DOC.HEAD: Air China Passengers Recall Hijack
DOC.TEXT: Passengers on an Air China jet hijacked en route from Beijing to New York said Sunday the flight was frightening even though they didn't know the plane had been commandeered until it landed in Japan. ``The rumors were spreading around the plane; we didn't know what was happening,'' said Ann Ofstedal, who said she had been studying for the past three years at a Beijing university. ``Even from talking to the crew, we could get very little information,'' she told reporters at San Francisco International Airport. ``They said they were also very worried.'' Flight 981 was flying from Beijing to New York via Shanghai and San Francisco on Saturday when Zhang Zhenai ordered the plane to fly to Seoul, South Korea. Korean authorities refused permission to land, and the plane was diverted to Fukuoka Airport on Japan's southern island of Kyushu. There, a purser reportedly pushed Zhang out the plane's rear door, shattering his legs and pelvis. He was being treated at a Japanese hospital. Authorities reported that Zhang, a 35-year-old cotton factory foreman, threatened crew members with a knife. He reportedly told Japanese police he participated in pro-democracy demonstrations in China last June and decided to flee after the crackdown. Ofstedal said the crew at one point asked passengers for rope. Although no one was told why it was needed, she said there was speculation an overwrought passenger needed to be subdued. Later, she said she heard Zhang had been tied up with the rope with the help of passengers. The plane returned to Beijing with 185 of its 200 passengers, including Zhang's wife and 10-year-old son. Police and airline officials said they did not know what happened to them, but foreign reporters saw the wife led from the plane in handcuffs. The flight to New York then resumed on a new aircraft. China's Civil Aviation Administration said most of the passengers were Chinese. Japanese police said there were 19 non-Chinese, including 12 Americans. Ofstedal said she became suspicious when the flight from Beijing to Shanghai, which normally takes 1 hour and 45 minutes, lasted more than two hours and the plane spent more than an hour circling a small island. ``People were acting very calm,'' she said, ``but it was obviously very tense.'' Wang Yuan of Beijing said she didn't realize a hijacking was taking place, although she and others were worried because the flight to Shanghai was taking so long. When the plane flew to Fukuoka, she said through a translator, passengers knew something was wrong when they looked out the windows and saw tall buildings and roadways full of cars, an unusual sight in China. Asked if she was sympathetic to Zhang's comments that he was motivated by fear of reprisals for speaking out against his government, Ofstedal replied, ``I think he could have chosen a better way.''
